q: In the Mundaka Upanishad, how do we interpret the parable of the two birds?
a:
The Mundaka Upanishad, one of the core texts of Vedanta, contains the parable of the two birds as described in the third chapter, 3.1.1 and 3.1.2. In this parable, there are two birds sitting on a tree. One bird is lower, while the other is higher. The lower bird represents the individual human being, who hops from branch to branch, which symbolizes our lives as we experience them now. This lower bird is engaged in the world, moving from one experience to another, tasting the "fruits" of various experiences, seeking happiness and satisfaction.

The higher bird, on the other hand, represents the divine or higher self, which remains uninvolved and merely observes the activities of the lower bird. This higher bird is not affected by the ups and downs of life, always remaining in a state of peace and bliss.

The interpretation of this parable is that our true nature is the higher bird, the divine self, which is untouched by the world and its experiences. However, we often identify ourselves with the lower bird, the individual self, and become entangled in the world and its dualities. The goal of spiritual life, according to Vedanta, is to realize our true nature as the higher bird, the divine self, and attain spiritual freedom. This can be achieved through practices such as meditation, self-inquiry, and selfless service, which help us disidentify with the lower bird and identify with the higher bird. By doing so, we can move from the unreal (the individual self) to the real (the divine self), from darkness (ignorance) to light (knowledge), and from death (limited existence) to immortality (unlimited existence).
